I was never very good at chemistry. It seemed to me to be a hopeless subject, full of equations that didn't make sense, where balancing the elements was considered an essential skill, where memory mattered, and where weird sounding names reacted to produce weirder compounds still. It didn't help that my family's take on chemistry was that all chemistry is physics, chemists merely handle the boring parts of physics. This all changed when I began to struggle and fail in high school, Year 11, and my parents hired a private tutor in desperation. Amit sir was gruff, down to earth and he spoke my language. Before he agreed to teach me, he sat with me for a trial class. He wanted to determine whether he could teach me at all, or not. After that first class, which I had been dreading, he got up, and told my parents that he would be fine with taking me on. Quite surprisingly, I found myself wanting to study chemistry, because this was the first lecture where I understood exactly what was going on.My dad at this point told Amit sir that chemistry has been a family disease, and sir took it as a challenge, and said "This is one disease I will cure."After that, he did whatever it took to get me to study. He would come early and play chess, he would entertain my endless questions far beyond the scope of the syllabus and he would research to answer whatever I asked. By the end of two years, of all my subjects, I scored the highest marks in chemistry.When I read this book today, I am able to appreciate and enjoy it because I understand the bones and the basics of chemistry, which would not have been possible without him. This is why I began my review with this anecdote.This book will probably be slightly dry and slow for people who have slogged through chemistry in high school, just to pass their exams. Most of those people will not make it through to the end of the book. To other people, who have had a strong base, and who enjoy learning about the stories that went into the discoveries of elements, to those people who revel in the factoids of science. This book tells the unusual stories that went into discovering the elements and the many applications of those elements and their unique nature and abilities.For me, this book rates as 4 stars, and not 3, because I'm able to appreciate and enjoy the obscure history in the discovery of the elements, but I can't in good conscience give it the same rating overall, because I know that there are many people who I would not recommend this book to.My ratings go somewhat like this:3 stars: The book was readable and I finished it comfortably, but I would not actively recommend it unless it suited someone.4 stars: I will recommend the book to most people without thinking twice.5 stars: I will force feed the book to people even if I have to tear it into tiny bits and push it down their throats.Because of this categorisation, this book sits squarely at 3 stars. There are parts of it that go into unnecessary and boring detail, but the book survives because the writer writes with intense passion, and those details are a side effect of that passion. That is something I'm happy to over look.To Summarise: Read it if you liked chemistry or if you want to know more about it. Otherwise, duck.

One of the prettiest books I have on my shelves right now is Theodore Gray's The Elements, a visual collection of all the elements that make up the physical universe. "Everything you can drop on your foot," as he says. In it, he provides wonderful pictures and descriptions of the elements that we know, arranged as they would be in the periodic table. It's a gorgeous book, one that everyone should have - especially if you have children. If you want your kids to become interested in science and investigating the world around them, you could do far worse than to have this book on your shelves.Eventually, though, they'll be old enough and canny enough to ask, "Well, how do we know all this? Where did we find these things, and how? And why are they in this order?" That's the point where you hand them The Disappearing Spoon, sit back, and let Sam Kean take over.The story of the elements, and our understanding of them, is governed just as much by personality as by p-shells, as much by competition as by charge, as much by ego as by electrons. While the elements themselves don't pay any attention to human affairs, the quest to understand the building blocks of matter have sent us to the hearts of stars, the depths of the earth and, for various reasons, Ytterby, Sweden. [1]Kean starts with how he got into the elements, with a story that would horrify modern-day parents: mercury. When he was a kid, his mother would collect the mercury from broken thermometers and keep it in a little bottle on a high shelf. If they were lucky, she would let her children play with it for a while, swirling it around and watching while this shiny liquid metal split apart and fused back together perfectly, never leaving a bit of itself behind. It was a metal that flowed like water, and it was fascinating. If he had known at that age that ancient alchemists thought there were spirits living in mercury, he would not have been surprised.Keeping an eye out for mercury, he learned that modern scientists are able to follow the expedition of Lewis and Clark using mercury. The explorers carried with them a good quantity of Dr. Benjamin Rush's Bilious Pills, a "cure" for any illness that mainly contained mercury chloride. It was vile stuff, poisoning everyone who took it, but without an FDA around to stop this kind of nonsense, Rush made plenty of money. It probably didn't hurt his credibility that he was one of the signers of the Declaration of Independence. In any case, he gave samples to the Lewis and Clark expedition, and their latrine sites can still be found today by the unusually high levels of mercury that were deposited there as the men's bodies tried to get rid of the heavy metal as quickly as possible.Mercury also taught Kean about mythology - the Roman god of communication, modeled on the Greek message-bearer. It taught him etymology - the chemical symbol for mercury is Hg, which is derived from the Latin hydragyrum, which means "silver water." It informed him on literature, especially the Mad Hatter of Alice in Wonderland, who was based on the poor crazies who used to breathe in the fumes of mercury while setting felt for their hats.This one weird, eerie element was a door into so many other topics that he figured there must be others. And so he started work on this book, a collection of histories and tales, gossip and hearsay, all centered around the 118 physical elements that make up our universe. "As we know," he writes, "90 percent of particles in the universe are hydrogen, and the other 10 percent are helium. Everything else, including six million billion billion kilos of earth, is a cosmic rounding error." Within that rounding error, though, some amazing things have been found.In the 19th century, the Russian Dimitri Mendeleev examined the common properties of different elements and was able to sort the elements in such a way that took advantage of their similarities. The violent alkalies along the far left, which will explode if given half a chance, and their cousins, the halogens on the far right, some of the most reactive elements in nature. Separating them are the noble gasses, which don't react with anything unless pushed to extremes. Without knowing about electron shells and the weird quantum things that happen on the atomic level, Mendeleev managed to put together a table so good that he was able to leave gaps in it that corresponded to elements that hadn't yet been found. And by telling the world that these gaps existed, the race to isolate and discover the elements was on.Kean's book is a great look at the way science works on a human level. How the search for high-quality porcelain led to the discovery of an entire class of elements, how Marie Curie would get into trouble by dragging her (male) colleagues into dark closets to show them how radium glowed, how nitrogen kills with kindness and lithium quiets an unsettled mind. The competition to not only find these elements but to name them and find uses for them has driven science forward in all fields, from geology to neurology, for the last two hundred years. Those 118 squares on the periodic table have driven men to travel the world, to create economic and political empires, to love, to hate, and to murder.If this kind of thing were taught in high school chemistry class, there would probably be a lot more kids interested in science as a career.The book is very readable, even if it does drift from time to time into more technical areas. One of my colleagues, who doesn't have an extensive background in science, said she was a little slowed down by talk of electron shells and quantum jumps, which I guess were not aided by Kean's elevator similes. But it did get her asking the right questions - how do we know atoms exist if we can't see them? How can we be sure that what is in this book is true? Those are the questions that Kean tries to answer in the book, but it's also the kind of book that may bring up more questions. It's "gateway science," one of those books that pulls away the cold, rational veneer of the scientist and his or her endeavors, and shows what an exciting, weird, messy and dramatic place science can be. What's more, it shows how science is deeply ingrained not only into our technology, but our language, history and politics. An understanding of science, even at an amateur level, is a wonderful way to open your eyes to the great, complex and bizarre world in which we live.-----------------------------------------------------------"We eat and breathe the periodic table; people bet and lose huge sums on it; philosophers use it to probe the meaning of science; it poisons people; it spawns wars. Between hydrogen at the top left and the man-made impossibilities lurking along the bottom, you can find bubbles, bombs, money, alchemy, petty politics, history, poison, crime, and love. Even some science."- Sam Kean, The Disappearing Spoon------------------------------------------------------------[1] The town has the distinct honor of having four elements named after it: yttrium (Y), ytterbium (Yb), terbium (Tb), and erbium (Er). What has your hometown got?

This is really interesting and well done. I enjoyed a lot of the details and anecdotes. I think at the end of the day though, I wanted more of the random anecdotes of the weird uses of some of the elements in the past, and less of the discussions on higher levels of physics and chemistry. The problem with higher level physics (less so chemistry, which I understand better), is that after a certain point it just sounds made up. I accept that it is not made up, and it is based on science, but if you don't know much about it, it's hard to latch onto some of the details, and I found myself skimming.I also think it's a touch long. It's a book of sort of randomly collected stories about the periodic table, but because the only overarching story is building the table itself, sometimes I again felt my mind drifting. I read this in fits and spurts over two weeks. It's not the kind of book you make it through in one sitting (though it did bring back any number of flashbacks on chemistry class).That said, I am delighted to learn that apparently Marie Curie used to haul male scientist colleagues into darkened closets to show them radium's glow (and associated radioactivity) with at least some regularity, and apparently on one occasion the demonstration was broken up by a colleague's suspicious spouse.2018 Reading Challenge - A microhistory

I found this book fascinating, with all of its tales regarding the periodic table and the scientists who spent their lives researching, testing and searching for the elements, and all of the anecdotes associated. The author, in turns, educated, entertained, surprised and delighted me. I want to read more of his books!

Because of the nature of the history of various elements on the table, this book felt a bit scatter-brained in scope and details. For all that, though, it was an excellent read and I learned a lot about various elements. It helps to have a least some basic knowledge of chemistry, but it's pretty easy to skim over anything you feel might be overly technical.

Checking off one from my far too many (just kidding...one can never have too many books to read) Small Stacks of Found Books that I kept setting aside for others, this is in one word a delight! Mr. Kean has done something marvelous here: making the periodic table fun and accessible! For science geeks (and professionals) it always has been, but for those less inclined...this is great.He says in his Introduction that from the one element mercury, he "learned history, etymology, alchemy, mythology, literature, poison forensics, and psychology." He also learned physics and chemistry, clearly, because it's all through this book, and politics that sometimes had play in the field. And Kean conveys the history and concepts in the best mystery page-turner style, along with humor and sagacity. Even if you know the history and concepts, the chemistry and physics (I'm not a neophyte to either), I suspect you'll learn something or somethings.Kean talks of the discoveries of the elements (and many of the gaffes), the origins of the table, the blanks and how they were filled. He delves into the biological interactions of some of the elements, from poisons to medicines, and how some elements mimic others, causing all kinds of havoc on the biological front. There is the politics of the Nobel prizes, the currency of elements, art and literature of elements. Something as seemingly simple as the Parker 51 pen gets copy time here, as the nibs were made of "durable ruthenium", "an element little better than scarp until then."Near absolute zero, bubble chambers, "Tools of Ridiculous Precision"...there is so much information here. I couldn't begin to summarize with any justice. I'll share one nugget to illustrate Kean's keen science. (Forgive, please!) There's a chapter on toxicity of exposure (or ingestion) and a GREAT observation I flagged. Great to me, anyway. In talking about William Crookes, his "lapse into spiritualism", and succumbing to "pathological science", Kean explains pathological science:In explaining what pathological science is, it's best to clear up any misconceptions about that loaded word, "pathological," and explain up front what pathological is not. It's not fraud, since the adherents of a pathological science believe they're right - if only everyone else could see it.(And here's the gem...It's not pseudoscience, like Freudianism and Marxism, fields that poach on the imprimatur of science yet shun the rigors of the scientific method.Love it! Pseudoscience! I've been saying so for years!It's also not politicized science, like Lysenkoism, where people swear allegiance to a false science because of threats or a skewed ideology. Finally, it's not general clinical madness or merely deranged belief. It's a particular madness, a meticulous and scientifically informed delusion. Pathological scientists pick out a marginal and unlikely phenomenon that appeals to them for whatever reason and bring all their scientific acumen to proving its existence.Kean says that a pathological science's "believers use the ambiguity about evidence as evidence - claiming that scientists don't know everything and therefore there's room for my pet theory, too."Read it. Highly recommended.

Anyone with an interest in science, whether you are just curious or science is your life's work, should read this book.I admit, I thought this book would be more of a curiosity, a sit down and leaf through it kind of book. Instead, I found it utterly engrossing on many different levels.I really enjoyed the stories-- the stories of people and personalities, of discoveries that were searched for over many years and those that accidentally fell into place, of friendships and partnerships and rivalries.I also enjoyed the science itself. I consider myself to be a scientifically inclined, so this isn't a surprise. I've got a solid background in chemistry and physics, even if I haven't thought about it in years, so the concepts weren't new. The first few chapters are much heavier on the science, lighter on the stories. If they get to be too much, flip further in and read a chapter. If that's more to your taste, then just skim through the rest of the first section. I do think this book is accessible to those with minimal scientific background-- I think my daughter learned enough in 5th grade science about atomic structure to understand most of the stories.I also think there is enough there for those that have been dedicated to science their entire lives. In this case, the names will be familiar, but I think the stories will be new, and they will even more fully appreciate following the paths in the history of the various elements.I'm thinking Christmas presents here, and I'm strongly considering buying some copies for my daughter's school.

This was an impulse buy- a symptom of my late in life discovery of science history. I never have had the single-minded concentration for pure science, but I loooove a good story. And this book is full of better than good stories. Plus, Kean is punny-- a clever word smith who never misses a chance for word play. E.g. In describing Ernest Rutherford's attempt to date Earth's creation: "Thorium then begets radium by spitting out another alpha particle. Radium begets radon with yet another, and radon begets polonium, and polonium begets stable lead."Kean also deserves credit for bringing the role of women in from the margins and even pokes a little fun at the latent sexism of a couple of scientists who couldn't figure out how they missed fission: "Fission escaped us, although it was called specifically to our attention by Ida Naddock, who sent us an article in which she clearly indicated the possibility... The reason for our blindness is not clear."Notables:- A teenager who built a nuclear reactor in his shed-Hiding gold from Nazis in plain sight-Legit origins of the story of King Midas-Gandhi's vendetta with iodine-Sir Isaac Newton's revenge on a counterfeiting heckler- public disembowlment-The mainstreaming of my granddaddy's metal- aluminum

The sensationalistic and often crude writing style marks Mr. Kean as the journalist that he is. Hence, the writing is sometimes more agenda driven and biased than one likes to see in a science text. With the emphasis on historical anecdotes, however, this is more forgivable. His ability to so frequently associate chemistry to sex is an interesting, but hardly commendable, talent. I would personally mark the swearing level as moderate (or whatever word one would use to mean “somewhere between mild and severe”).Despite my lack of enthusiasm for the style, I learned a ton from this book. One of the things I like most about it is its ability to show how chemistry links in with other sciences. It shows many cool relationships. Most high school science courses mistakenly take each subject alone and disassociate it from any other. This book would pretty effectively combat that failing. Hence, I think it would work very well as supplemental reading for a high school or college chemistry course. I would, of course, be sure to mention the above caveats to anyone I recommended this book to.

This book rocked my world. I mostly daydreamed through chemistry class in high school, and would rather have knocked my head against a wall repetitively than studied it in college - so needless to say, I learned a lot from Kean's insights.I won't lie, the theoretical chemistry and quantum mechanics went about ten miles over my head, but I'm friggin' in love with all the history and mystery surrounding the elements. I feel like I finally have a grip on what makes up our world. Not to mention how awesome it is to understand some of the great scientific discoveries made over the centuries: how we've determined the Earth's age, the steps of radioactive decay, potential silicon-based alien life, etc. This is the perfect book for intelligent people who didn't major in chemistry, but still want to understand and appreciate our periodic table. Kean doesn't come across as a pompous ass or talk down to the reader--he hits that sweet spot in between. Both informative and entertaining.Read on, fellow nerds!

Every college chemistry teacher should read this book! I've taken so many college/university-level chemistry classes, yet author Sam Kean is the first person who managed to explain the periodic table in a way that makes sense and is memorable without a lot of memorization. I now understand the way the elements relate to each other better than I ever have, even though my last chemistry class was over 14 years ago. The anecdotes about the different elements and the men and women who discovered them are entertaining, but the periodic table is the real star of this book. There are a few small sections that may be over the head of anyone who isn't familiar the behavior of electrons, for example, but it's easy enough to just skim over those pages to get back to the anecdotes. This is an excellent book for the armchair scientist, trivia enthusiast, history buff, or anyone who enjoys understanding more about the world around them. The endnotes alone are wonderfully entertaining.

I'm going to say that I feel like Mr.Kean took everything he knew about the periodic table of elements and vomited it into this book. I really enjoy the tidbits of information but I dislike to organizational format. Mr. Kean walks you through the table by introducing you elements related in properties. I personally would have preferred a chronological narrative. I felt like the players were coming in and out of the story- the table evolved and devolved. In one chapter is the late 90s race for heavy metals and the next chapter is pre-table with a different community of chemists. In spite of the jumpy time table, I think it's worth the read. I found it very thought provoking as a relative stranger to chemistry. However, don't expect a book that reads like a novel.

Got this out of the library a while back, mainly for my wife who teaches chemistry, as a general book for her to maybe recommend to her students.Overall is is quite good. It is a science book that is written in a style that could be described as conversational. It has some humour in it, and lots of facts, anecdotes and tales of the the individuals who made the science of chemistry what it is today. One of the most fascinating is the discovery of a natural nuclear power station that has been running for 1.7 billion years.I have only given four stars as I feel that the book Periodic Tales, is much better at explaining the elements.

Who knew science was about love, war and practical jokes like disappearing spoons? As an engineer who once considered majoring in chemistry, I thoroughly enjoyed this book. Sometimes science can be rather dry, but learning the twists and turns of its history really makes it interesting. I always wondered why my European coworkers always referred to "aluminum" as "aluminium". Question now answered! This book is full of fun stories and anecdotes that I've been having fun sharing with my husband. He can't wait to read the book himself.

I think I will buy this for my little chemist as she goes off to college :)Other than chap. 16 which was a bit over my head, this was an enjoyable, informative read for a layperson. I have always been intrigued by the elegance of math and science. Through anecdotes, Sam Kean give the reader a glimpse at Marie Curie's work, the disappearing gallium spoon, the stories of zirconia and aluminum, the mentos dropped in cola experiment, etc.

I wish this book had existed when I took high school chemistry. These interesting "real world" stories about the elements we don't notice in our day to day lives could have helped jump start learning so much information. This book is rather like a series of short stories, easy to dip into and to read a bit here and a little more later. One complaint is that the footnotes, which are interesting and worth reading, are at the back of the book rather than at the bottom of the page.

Caleb and I listened to this together, and we both loved it. however this book isn't for everyone; if you hated high school chemistry, don't bother. But if you almost let your husband convince you to name your firstborn "Molybdenum" (Molly for short), you will love this book, as did I. (We named her Alaina instead. I think it was for the best.)The ending dragged on a bit, but overall it was a great chemistry refresher with lots of fascinating stories from history intertwined.

Great, as usual. It's my second book by Sam Kean that I read, and I love it's style.Every chapter is a trip within the periodic table where you will meet elements and the people, often unknown to the greatest public, that helped us to understand such element. You can easily read the book if you have a scholastic knowledge of chemistry.

This was a fun book: learn some chemistry, some basic physics, some history, and some information about many of the people who made key discoveries that made the modern world possible. It is all written in an easy to understand way that is accessible to the casual reader, and it’s not even necessary to read the chapters in order. The author has an engaging writing style and the book never seemed to drag. I would definitely recommend it to people whose children show some interest in science.

Fun and informative read, it was really easy to read and not overwhelmingly technical. I learned wolfram is the old name for the element tungsten and how instrumental it was in WWII, an interesting speculation on Bronze Age Turkey and the King Midas myth, and lots of other wonderfully random tidbits.

Fascinating! Stories woven with the science. I wish this book had existed at the time I took my first (and last) Chemistry class - I'm sure I still would have struggled (a scientist I am not, and parts of this book made my poor brain hurt) but the stories and context made it interesting and understandable.

A very fun ride through the periodic table. Packed full of useful trivia this book is sure to please science lovers! It reads like an anthology of elements - more short stories compiled together than one cohesive narrative. I really enjoyed it though. If you love to read about the history of science, I highly recommend this book.

I liked this book. Lots of fun anecdotes, a little bit of physics, and a whole lot of history of chemistry.Kean does give an uncomfortable amount of attention to speculation that the fine structure constant is inconstant.

This book was surprising. It was full of stories with the science layered in for color. It was much more about the people that helped shape our understanding of chemistry than about hardcore science, though it was a good refresher on my high school chemistry.

I absolutely loved this book, it was so interesting and really kept me reading. It wasn't easy however, as the material is pretty dense, so it did take me quite a while to read. It definitely was worth it though, I really enjoyed it and found it fascinating to learn about.

Ok so I must start of with the following disclaimer: I have been out of highschool 20+ years.I enjoyed listening to all the great stories on how the elements were discovered and used. The scientific explinations sometimes went over my head, but I still enjoyed the book.

A very nice read. Chemistry never was my favourite subject in school, but I surprisingly enjoyed this book. Kean is quite the narrator, taking one through the annals of the periodic table and its associated elements. Definitely worth a read for anyone looking for a good pop science book.
LOVED this book. Fascinating stories of the people and the science and the history of the periodic table. Really accessible and funny.
Super interesting. I should read this again.
Can't wait to add lessons I learned from this book into my classroom!
This was FASCINATING. "Book that is a microhistory" for my 2018 Reading Challenge.

Chemistry was my favorite science in high school --- I liked the math, the predictability and experiments. This book brought back some of that wonder that I had as a young student. I listened to the audio which was read by the author. His enthusiasm was quite infectious and added to my enjoyment. I'm pretty sure that my eyes would have glazed over trying to read all though obscure elements (that weren't around when I was in high school!!).This is laid out as a series of vignettes --- organized by sets of elements. The stories are often about the people and the crazy competitive world of science. With the periodic table as the outline, Kean discusses everything from "the big bang" to the pathological science of spiritualism, and from self experiments and crazy medical practices that led us to trace the route of Lewis and Clark. While I won't pretend that I understood everything nor even remember most of it (even though it was very readable as a lay person) --- I am taking away a few tidbits. For example, I had no idea that chemistry and physics were so related and Krypton is actually an element (not just Superman's home planet). I would definitely recommend this for anyone with a passing interest in science, history and trivia.

I absolutely loved this book with its deep dive into curious details about the elements and the periodic table. Kean does a far better job of explaining how the periodic table helps organize our understanding of the elements and their chemistry and physics than any of my grade school teachers ever did, but then that may be partially because I'm an adult who actually wants to learn rather than a kid who is fucking around half the time. I like how he included lots of details about how the various elements were discovered, and the sometimes nasty politics and rivalry that went along with it, and the frequent missteps and mistakes. I like science books that give me new understanding that I didn't have before, and for a specific example I never understood why the larger transitional metals behaved so weirdly, and didn't follow a simple chemical pathways, until he explained the fact that the electrons in the d-shell get buried behind other layers (and this principle applies to even large elements moving up to the f-shell, etc.) making the different chemical behavior of these elements complex and difficult to tease apart. I also liked his explanations of radioactivity and how it relates to the periodic table.

I have always been fascinated with Chemistry. If I hadn't chosen Physics, I would have definitely learnt Chemistry at University. My interest in chemistry stems from how miniscule changes in the structure of atoms can have profound changes in their behaviour. And that's what the Periodic Table is all about, isn't it? The book was wonderful. It discusses each element in great detail, including its chemistry and origins. New elements have rapidly advanced our society: every element discovered has found a niche use and some elements have gone on to become so ubiquitous today that life without them is unimaginable (take Silicon for example). If anything, I'm a sucker for good science stories about the great men of science. I have read tons of such stories and anecdotes (just have a look at the books I've read and you will start to understand). Still, this book managed to give me tons of new stories about people I know and admire. It also introduced me to new people I admire now and raised my admiration of people whom I previously thought as fringe contributors. All in all, it was an enjoyable read and makes you really wonder how a simple table arrangement has shaped the world as it is today.

What a great fun non-fiction book! Perhaps this one just plays to my biases and interests, but I found this book and its look at the elements of the periodic table to be filled with interesting tidbits and trivia. Some of it I knew - I should hope so, seeing that I've been a pharmacist for over 40 years - but others bits were things that were fascinating side trips into the development of chemistry and physics. But there was much more here - star science, the Big Bang, dinosaurs, history, warfare, the development of sulfonamides and l-dopa, the use of lithium to treat manic-depression, sexism in science, nuclear fission, and the race to figure out the structure of DNA. This is not a dry examination of chemical elements - it's a fun trip discovering the basic building blocks of our world and the men and women who've strived through the ages to bring order and explanation to how they work. Wow, just wow.

I was surprised at how much I enjoyed this book. A book about the periodic table - there were several topics over my head but it definitely sparked interest and brought tough chemistry and physics topics down to a non-chemist level. The addition of real stories, connections with history and literature were entertaining and informative. I actually listened to some of the book (the audio was great) and read most. I highly recommend reading the author notes in the back as you read the chapters (the audio does it automatically). Note: for those that care, this book is not written from a Christian worldview

This book had so much potential! A self-proclaimed nerd, I was excited about the idea of bringing a story-telling element (no pun intended) into science, to scratch the same itch that great historical fiction does. But I was disappointed. The actual tale of the disappearing spoon lasted about two sentences, and most of the other tales were either short-lived, uninteresting, pedantic, or disorganized. The structure of the book made me dizzy, the bad metaphors were hard to swallow, and the juxtaposition of a casual tone with unnecessarily esoteric vocabulary made it far too easy to put this book down. I learned a few things, but I’m not sure it was worth it.

More than anything, politics proved the folly of scientists burying their heads in lab work and hoping the world around them figured out its problems as tidily as they did their equations.In 2015, I read an article on argyria and the Smurf-like qualities it produced and was both amused and mesmerized so much so that I did a presentation on ‘Spooky Tales from the Periodic Table’ for my college chemistry class. Digging a little led me to this book and having read and enjoyed Kean’s previous work, The Violinist’s Thumb, I had to get my hands on it.This was easier said than done because for the life of me I could not find this anywhere until Shika gifted me a copy a while ago (Thanks again Shiks!!).Kean’s enthusiasm for the periodic table shines through even with his subtle favoritism of American science hard to ignore (Americanizing aluminium to aluminum does not make it sound more premium in my opinion despite being reminiscent of platinum). Kean’s explanations are thorough, smart and well written leaving no room for confusion.Looking forward to reading more from him!

I found this easy to pick up and hard to put down. Interesting book with an un-textbook-like telling. Still, it was over my head at times. Some of the passages were difficult for me to get through and I found myself having to reread multiple times. Yet others flowed nicely. That was likely due to my lack of knowledge, not the author's writing. I enjoyed the combination of science, history, and the "behind the scenes" view. This was very charming. A lot of cute anecdotes about elements. I don't know if I have a lot else to say about it -- it seems designed for people who like cute anecdotes about physics and chemistry.

FINALLY DONE with this book. I just aimed to finish it. It was interesting, but slow and the longer it took, the more annoying reading it was. Overall I enjoyed the topics but the format was difficult to read.
It can live somewhere between a 3 and a 4
I love books like this - anecdotal gems butting up against history and science. Fascinating and entertaining.

Every time I read a non-fiction book I tell myself: "So much knowledge that I'll never be able to remember! What a fantastic job of gathering and structuring information!" and this book wasn't any different. I really like how the author structured the different themes and felt that the transitions between the stories and the different elements were pretty flawless. And it was really funny too!The only negative thing I have to say about this book is that it might be quite complicated for someone who doesn't have a basic knowledge of chemistry. Some parts brought me back to school and I had to think hard to comprehend some concepts again, so I can't imagine for someone who didn't study it at all. But I'm kind of glad that he didn't explain everything from scratch, as that would have made some parts a bit boring. All in all, I great non-fiction read for anyone interested in science!

At first glance, a book about the periodic table of the elements may sound boring. They're elements, and only a handful are ones you've even really heard or care about, like hydrogen and oxygen and carbon and whatever. Who wants to know about rhenium or ytterbium? You, that's who, because Sam Kean is going to take you on a whirlwind journey through the fundamental makeup of the goddamn universe.The Disappearing Spoon begins with a personal story about Sam Kean's fascination of mercury (Hg), which led to his fascination with the rest of the elements. Kean's book tackles a whole host of topics: subatomic particles, discovery of natural elements, creation of artificial elements, scientific rivalries, the Nobel Prize, quantum mechanics, the design of the periodic table itself, wacky element-related anecdotes, it's a lot. I learned so much cool information and random trivia I've already forgotten most of it because wow. While it pretends to have a structure that moves through the periodic table in an organized fashion, it's all for show because really Kean just jumps around and digs into stories.And that's what this book is. It's a collection of stories. It shines a light on scientists throughout history (and Kean absolutely highlights the many women overshadowed by their male counterparts), and it finds the whimsy in the world, like the fact that SEVEN FUCKING ELEMENTS WERE DISCOVERED ON ONE ISLAND. And four were named directly for it. Oh boy, there is so much element-naming drama in this book. Audiobook reader Sean Runnette is anything but dry, as he keys into Kean's sensibilities and turns the constant appearance of UC Berkeley into an amusing running gag.While the majority of the book is perfectly comprehensible for a layman, even I had trouble following some of the more detailed sections explaining chemistry and subatomic physics, which are not dumbed down sufficiently enough. There are metaphors available, Kean! Throw me a bone here!The Disappearing Spoon gave me a much greater appreciation for the periodic table and all the elements that reside there, not to mention the general pursuit of science and the curiosity to understand the universe. There's a lot more to care about than hydrogen and oxygen and carbon and whatever.

The Disappearing Spoon: And Other True Tales of Madness, Love, and the History of the World from the Periodic Table of the Elements (or as I like to call it, "SCIENCE!") by Sam Kean is a well-written, anecdotal exploration of the history of periodic table and its influences on modern science. The author faithfully covers every known element, detailing its discovery while also discussing the current goings on in the scientific community at that time, and why (or if) those elements are important today.Back to the first days when chemistry started to evolve out of alchemy, to the beginnings of scientific method in Victorian times, through the separation of atomic physics from chemistry, all the way to current (circa 2000s) discoveries. As Kean, hops through time on his elemental trail (don't worry, each section is chemically or thematically connected) the little ridiculous stories that inevitably pop-up when discussing some of the rather quixotic notables of science, provide an amazing mnemonic for the most inane of facts. And some of the stories are almost too ridiculous to be true -- did you know that there was a naturally occurring nuclear reactor in Africa, up until a couple hundred thousand years ago?If you fashion yourself a chemistry, physics, or even just a history geek, you should read this book -- I guarantee you will spend infinitely more time chuckling than you did when you were reading your textbooks.5*/5*

In The Disappearing Spoon, Sam Kean takes a stroll through one of the greatest achievements of humankind, what he calls “an anthropological marvel”: the Periodic Table. He details each element as a story; a witty, informative and sometimes bizarre anecdote from the history of the Table. This book is a must-read for everyone, even those who don’t have an interest in chemistry. And for those that do, you will love it even more, from cover to cover and for each and every element.  Sean Kean writes with a contagious enthusiasm that only comes from loving and respecting the subject for years, all the way back to when he started collecting mercury from broken thermometers. From naming a virus after its amino acids with a 1,185-letter word, to pranking an unsuspecting peer with a melting gallium spoon, Kean artfully brings together the science of the elements and the tales of the “(frequently) mad scientists who discovered them”. All in all, he shows us that what may seem like a (while ingenious) plain and uninteresting table actually has a rich and absorbing history. I loved this book for the way it is written, how Kean weaves his words so that this book isn't just informative; it's entertaining. The subject of the Table is often very difficult to write about without sounding like the white noise in an airplane, yet the tales he spins are more engaging than any other. There may not be a cohesive theme, characters or development of such, nevertheless, he captivated me with his "true tales of madness, love and the history of the world".
This dude is inexplicably obsessed with alliteration.

3.5 stars for writing style (a bit scattered) but 4 stars for content - recommended for anyone who wishes they could retake Chemistry or Physics as an adult and actually appreciate it. A very interesting look at the history of the Periodic Table and the elements that shape our world. It read less like a novel and more like a series of related essays - but with the amount of information included it was really the only way to do it. Also, while there is a lot of information it is presented in a user-friendly and entertaining fashion. This book did require a fair amount of thinking to understand some of the concepts but that's why it was fun - challenging but not overwhelming. There are many areas of science I want to know more about but don't have the time or inclination to study academic journals in the field. I'm seeing an increase of works written in a "popular science" style and loving it.I will certainly read his second novel - The Violinist's Thumb: And Other Lost Tales of Love, War, and Genius, as Written by Our Genetic Code

This book was a really fun lens to look at science history through. The history of the elements is so tightly woven into the history of civilization and modern society that Sam Kean has no trouble making the periodic table come to life. His love for the elements and their 'personalities' is contagious. I spent quite a few nights between this book and my Visual Exploration of Every Known Element book. If you don't read this book, but you want to pretend you know what the title refers to just search 'melting gallium spoon'. "Now if you translate quantum mechanics into English, always risky, the equation says that the uncertainty in something's position (delta X) times the uncertainty in its speed and direction, its momentum (delta P), always exceeds or is greater to the number H divided by 4 times Pi. The H stands for Plunk's constant which is such a small number, about one hundred trillion trillion times smaller than one, that the uncertainty principle applies only to tiny, tiny things such as electrons or photons. In other words, if you know a particles position very well, you cannot know its momentum well at all, and visa versa. Note that these uncertainties aren't uncertainties about measuring things, as if you had a bad ruler. They are uncertainties built into nature itself."

Sam Kean, an admitted mercury chaser as a youth, has written an interesting book about the ever present Periodic Table of Elements found in nearly every science classroom beginning in elementary school. Did you know the shape of the chart is significant? Do you wonder about the scientists who discovered these elements? Do you think the chart should be re-organized? If you are thinking seriously about any of these questions, you really need to read this book.Gallium is an interesting element, so much so that Mr. Kean alluded to it in the title of his book. You can see the disappearing spoon experiment on Youtube!Then there's Stan Jones, the Libertarian who ran for the US Senate in 2002. In an attempt to ready himself for the lack of antibiotics in the Y2K millenium scare, he began distilling heavy silver metal "moonshine" in his backyard. Drinking his concoction for four and a half years, he contracted argyria and turned "startlingly blue." Jones stated shortly after his electoral loss, "..If there were a biological attack on America or if I came down with any type of disease, I'd immediately take it again. Being alive is more important than turning purple." (p. 173)Read about these and other interesting tales in this book!

Chemistry was distinctly not my thing in my college days. This book was on a “top 10 science books of 2010″ list, however, so I picked it up. It did not disappoint. I’d compare it to Bryson’s “Short History of Nearly Everything” in that it illuminates the scientific concepts by telling the tales of the individuals who made the discoveries or, in some cases, were affected by quirks of chemistry. I found the writing graceful and clear but it wass dense and I found myself skipping back frequently. Drift off for a moment and you could be quickly lost. My issue with chemistry (and where it overlaps with quantum physics) is that I have a hard time seeing its relevance to my own life. I enjoyed learning this stuff for interest’s sake but so much of it seems a bit, well, “out there” and irrelevant. To some degree, this book helped me see the importance of chemistry and quantum physics in our technological era but I did not feel like much of this will really stick with me and shape my view of the world. Clearly the author knows and loves his subject matter. As an introduction to chemistry I give it a big thumbs up but my next book will be back in my home turf of the biological sciences.

The Disappearing Spoon: And Other True Tales of Madness, Love, and the History of the World From the Periodic Table of the Elements by Sam Kean★★★When I was in high school, I took chemistry... and failed it. In college, I was a science major (at least for the first two years) so I took chemistry…and failed it. So then I took an easier chemistry class (aka “easiest” class possible)… and failed it. And then I changed my major to history, for obvious reasons. So it’s great that after all these years, I have found a book that actually makes me understand something about the field, even if it is the basics (which is honestly more than I grasped before). The author lost me in some places, such as the discussions on quantum mechanics and physics (did I mention I didn’t do well in physics either?). I feel like the book started out strongly but towards the end I just got bored, which could be more due to my lack of understanding than the book itself. A good read if one is looking at learning more about the basics of science with a mixture of history added in. There were some amusing stories found throughout the book and interesting people mentioned. Definitely a well researched book.

Read for a library book club.I could care less about chemistry. Then came Mr. Kean. I did not want to read this book. An entire book about the periodic table? No. Thank. You.Mr. Kean got just about everything right. If Mr. Kean and MythBusters had been around when I was in middle and high school, I would have been absolutely fascinated by science. Mr. Kean has dug up unbelievably amazing stories about each element - what scientists have done in order to become famous, make a discovery, be of value to their country - and told them in a wholly engaging way.My only complaint about The Disappearing Spoon is the conflict Mr. Kean has between providing a scientific document explaining science on an atomic level and creating a text the common non-chemistry-loving reader will understand. At times the sections about protons and electrons ran long and were distracting.That said, I do feel I have a better understanding of how elements work with or against each other, how they change or don't change, and that is a lot more than can be said for years of public science classes.Mr. Kean is an asset to the science community by making science interesting to those who don't like science.

Listened to this book (13 hours!) on a trip last week. Very interesting stories, particularly the radioactive boy scout and lots about the scientists who discovered the elements and the politics behind the stories. Some I had heard before, like the Watson/Crick "discovery" of the double helix, for which others should have shared int he credit. I particularly liked the discussions about how chemicals have improved our lives, including the author's assertion that we are who we are because of specific chemical interactions (I need to get the book to check this one out more). Kean also spends time talking about the possibility that Earth is not alone in the universe, what aliens might look like, and other theoretical questions. All the time I was reading it, I wondered how all of this could have developed without intelligent design - God. The negative in reading a book like this is that you have to listen to all of the author's theorizing, notes (most of which were interesting), and you can't skip the boring parts. I'd suggest reading it rather than listening. Otherwise, a good book.

A very entertaining as well as informative read. Kean takes us through a tour of the periodic table of elements, the mainstay of chemistry and physics. As exciting as that sounds (or not), the tour actually includes murder and madness, love and attraction, and a whole lot of history. Early in the book the focus is on the development of the table itself as scientists started to notice patterns of characteristics. Not surprisingly, these patterns relate to the deep-diving chemistry and physics of elements and you'll probably learn more about orbital shells and subatomic anatomy through this book than your introductory science class. The author goes on to examine specific elements and groups of elements as they come to be known, all while giving a voyeur's look into the often mischievous (and sometimes mad) world of the scientists - both male and female - who discovered them. Most science and history loving readers should find this book fascinating. Kean's writing style is jam-packed with information and yet easy to read. And even sometimes downright fun. The book is definitely worth reading.

The Case of the Disappearing Spoon by Sam Kean was surprisingly one of the most entertaining books I've read all year. Sam Kean chose a very intelligent subject yet made it understandable using antidotes make me care about the development of the periodic table. Why would I even try this book? Why would I even care about this book? Well, I don't know about you but after spending three years staring at it and never really learning it's true importance. I finally wanted to comprehend and learn to respect the ding dang thing. I was surprised how many historical events I already knew about but never recognized the scientific significance they represented. The only boring part was the "longest names" section which was a very short section and the only scary part was the true description of and my now understanding of what a "dirty bomb" is and yup, that could keep me up at night.I'll be honest, my plan was going to make this my book to read on the stair master over a month. I ended up sucking this book down in four days. I wish Kean had been anyone of my science teachers in high school. I would have been a hardcore science geek for sure and proud of it!

Other than his style of footnoting, which I found distracting, this was an outstanding book on the history of science, told through the elements of the periodic table. While technically a book about chemistry, it actually wanders into biology, nuclear physics, astrophysics, alchemy, theology and a host of other areas, not all of them purely scientific. Some of the odd scandals and pseudo-scandals of science have a lot to do with popular culture and societal beliefs.While some of the sections use formulas that may seem strange and scary, the explanations are clear and concise, so don't panic if you hit a brief bit of math or physics that you've forgotten, or never learned.The problem with the footnotes is that all of them refer to a section in the back of the book, but not all are equally relevant to the text. Sometimes the footnote is a clarification, sometimes a related anecdote, sometimes a bizarre sidestep. They're almost all entertaining, but each one takes the reader away from the main text, both physically (lots of page flipping) and mentally.

I enjoyed reading this book. It is a good mixture of stories, theories, facts, and trivia related to the periodic table (but much more interesting than that might sound). The author strikes a good balance between explaining the chemistry and telling related stories in an entertaining way. Along the way, he covers the "human side" of the scientists who made key discoveries related to the periodic table; how science is affected by both commerce and politics, even office politics within labs; the elements in our bodies, the Earth, and the universe; how man has used elements throughout the years; and much more. I learned a lot, and was proud that some of the theories the author explained were still vaguely familiar to me from my high school chemistry class. If you do read this book, I'd approach it as a collection of short stories/anecdotes, rather than a book with an overarching narrative, though you might expect that based on the title. If you have the time and the interest, it's worth the read.

I think I'm officially a geek's geek because I thoroughly enjoyed Kean's book on elements and the periodic table. By virtue of moving about every 1.5 years during my K-12 (no kindergarten for me, thankfully) years, by the time I got to the last school I would attend in this period, I had enough credits, with my voluntary attendance at summer school between 10th grade and 11th grade to get a last English credit I would need to graduate, to graduate a year early.Because of that, I missed taking chemistry in high school (I skipped straight from biology in 10th grade to physics in 11th grade), so this book was my first foray into the basics - and not so basics - of chemistry, the elements and the periodic table.Kean redeemed himself with me in this book as he unveiled for me the world of chemistry, elements, and the periodic table (with his usual flair for the quirky, fascinating, and little-known stories behind it all) enough to really peak my interest in doing more study into the subject.Excellent book.

I love all the various facts, anecdotes, and bits of history the author uses to help you understand each element of the periodic table. I actually want to reread this at some point and try to absorb more of the information in this book. Some of the author’s stories really stick with you and help you really understand how particular element functions or the history of the discovery of that particular element. The story that stuck with me was the fact that if you were to breath in 100% nitrogen, your body has no capacity to realize that it is not getting oxygen. As the author explains, our bodies actually don’t monitor that we have enough oxygen, just that we don’t have too much carbon dioxide. In a 100% nitrogen environment you could still expel carbon dioxide, so you will calmly breath in this air and minutes later fall down dead, never knowing, before you died, that anything was wrong. (The author uses the example of the death of some NASA employees to illustrate this happening in real life.)

This is the kind of science book I really enjoy. It's written for the layperson, it has a lot of really interesting stories, and it focuses a lot on the people behind the science and gives the human element (see also A Short History of Nearly Everything). I love that I now know why lithium works in helping people cope with depression and bipolar disorder (and it's such a fascinating reason!), and that I better understand some of the chemistry involved in the periodic table. I also definitively learned that I am not good with physics. Which I always knew, but have now confirmed.Is this a book that will stick with me forever? Probably not. Is it a worthwhile read (or listen--the audio was great)? Yes, definitely. If you are at all interested in science, and in the basic components of the universe, I think you'll enjoy this book.

I freakin' loved this book. Kean's voice is charming and compelling, and his take on these stories are filled with humor and affection. He clearly loves science and loves scientists and passes this fascination on with story after story of quirky personalities, and strange properties, and mind-blowing physics and chemistry. For instance did you know that 1.6 million years ago, there was a natural nuclear fission generator in Africa? Or that that during WWI the German's sent spys into colorado to take over a molybednum mine (to make their big bertha guns), and they were totally successful. Or that the first three scientists to theorize, create, and recognize nuclear fission were all women? Or that the scientist who created nitrogen fertalizer and saved miliions of lives also created mustard gas and took thousands (and drove his brillant wife to suicide). Seriously, the best book!

Fascinating! This should be required reading in all chemistry classes. This book breathes life and drama into chemistry and physics.Kean is a very accessible writer and makes complicated chemistry and physics intelligible to the common person. I was enthralled by his stories (plus I loved his witty commentary and parenthetical asides) and found it fun when he mentioned people I knew by name only due to some law or element named after them. I loved chemistry in high school and college but I would have loved a deeper understanding of its history rather than just formulas and theorems. One minor quibble: I would have preferred footnotes to the end notes Kean used. The endnotes were entertaining and I would have liked the immediate context vs reading them at the end. I also enjoyed having a reading list and look forward to checking those books out. Excellent read! Highly recommend!!

At its best, this book is an engaging, interesting, and deeply informative book about the birth of modern chemistry.At its worst, it is a poorly edited gossip rag that takes indiscriminate potshots -- criticizing scientists for believing too readily, not believing readily enough -- and is filled with unfortunate, cynical schadenfreude.As to the editing -- Timothy McVeigh did NOT blow up the Oklahoma City Courthouse. He blew up the Murrah Federal Building. That is a MAJOR error that should not have gotten past the editors.Finally, Mr Kean, while ridiculing pretty much everyone, consistently talks about what atoms and molecules and elements "want to do." As the hard-nosed, error-free science writer, he ought to know that atoms, etc., don't "want" anything. They DO things because of their various physical properties.That is a whole lot of complaining, but I mostly enjoyed this. Mr Kean just needs a dose of the humility that he noticing that others don't have.

I started reading this book because of an excellent recommendation from a friend but in the end I wasn't as enamored as she was. First off, I needed to keep a periodic table handy to keep track of the elements, makes reading and relating to the stories easier. Got to be honest too, chemistry was my worst subject, I understood the basic proton, electron, neutron stuff but start with the charges and the bonding and my eyes start to glaze over. Some of the chapters were more alluring than others- I particularly liked Parts II and IV, the chapter on the poisoner's corridor. There were some paragraphs in the latter part of the book where I was tempted to skim over but I stuck with it. And I can say agree with my friend that it was a definite sense of accomplishment to finish this book and be able to understand it. I loved the stories and learnt a lot. Sure wish this was available when I was in school, would have made chemistry a lot more interesting.

This is an interesting, quirky book with two major flaws. The book takes the periodic table and the elements represented there as its subject matter. There are a surprising number of interesting stories and historical facts to tell. I learned a fair amount, though some of the science was over my head, and was entertained by many of the stories. Even so, the flaws were hard for me to forgive. The book is VERY choppy, jumping from story to story and subject to subject without so much as a chapter heading, subheading, or transition to guide the way. The author also uses a very informal writing style which drove me nuts. There were lots of fragments and run-ons and more dashes than any author should ever be allowed to use in one book. I found myself wanting to introduce the author to the semicolon and its varied and valuable uses. I know this makes me sounds like a grammar snob, but I only complain about grammar when it interferes with meaning and the flow of the writing. Here it did.

This guy knows a lot about chemistry, maybe not so much about spiritualistic matters. I think the chapter on Crooke and spiritualism was a bit too ofensive. I have already read another book of his and unfortunately this thing (being a very spiritualistic person myself) probably caused me a bad impression. Also, for as much as I like this book and recognize a lot of information that I have already studied, (from reliabe sources) I have doubts if some of his versions are thaaat acurate... With these two points aside, I think it is a great book. I recomend it for those who hated chemistry classes, for those who never had chemistry classes, for those who soon will start to study chemistry... It is nice, fun to read, not a little bit technical and you might learn a lot. (Always good to have incredible facts to use in bar conversations) Do you know that many dinosaurs might have died of pneumonoconiosis?I do. :-)

In the vein of Stephan Jay Gould and Olive Sacks, Sam Kean puts together an essay collection of stories built around the creation of and the periodic table. Each chapter tackles a group of the elements regarding the phenomena we call atoms, and how they structure to create different things and interact in different ways. Historical stories about the discoveries, the elemental explorers, and scientific properties provides for an enriching read on multiple levels (mental shells?) SK adds in just enough informal language (and swear words) to keep the attention and make this book just a straight-forward "and this" kinda book. He does a great job constructing the themes around each chapter of grouped elements, and the transitions within chapters create a smart and fluid narrative.Kudos Sam!.

There are some very interesting stories in this book (my favorite being the one about a couple of Nobel Prize medals being dissolved to hide them during WWII), but there were also some long, boring parts about, like, electrons and stuff. Obviously I expected this book to be science-y, but for someone like me who is really, really not science-oriented, those passages detailing processes or why elements work the way they do, for example, caused me to zone out. I probably won't be remembering the names of too many scientists mentioned, or the atomic numbers of elements, or even the symbols for certain obscure elements, but I'm glad I read this book, if only for what little education I took from it.

fun for sure, but not that much material that was really new to a reader of e.g.  The Periodic Kingdom, and really it was the poppiest of pop science, with only one equation and not even a serious attempt at hand-waving, and there were a few glaring errors, and at one point while discussing europium's use in anti-counterfeiting he says, "it's reportedly banned to research" which what the fuck is this "reportedly" business; you're the goddamn author, go find out. his footnotes ought have just been in the text; it wasn't like they were much more deep.

I think my family's reaction to this book may be a good guide for everyone. I'm a history buff, but a bit science-blocked, so while I loved the anecdotes about discovery and invention, I probably won't remember much of the science. The last few chapters went right over my head. My son, on the other hand, is a science major, and didn't find the book nearly informative enough, so he gave it up. This is definitely science for the layperson: the person who's more likely to remember Marie Curie's flouting of social norms than to understand what she actually did with radiation. But if you're one of those, you will pick up some things here and there, so the book is worth your while.

As promised, this book delivers interesting stories about elements, the periodic table, and scientists and other people who have been involved with them. The writing is engaging, with pretty good explanations of the scientific details. When we learn these things in high school, they seem pretty set in stone, so I was surprised at some of the developments that have happened since then. Details of old stories are interesting, too. I enjoyed reading some of them aloud to the boys, though the AP Physics student knew quite a few already, and the AP Chem student probably wasn't listening.

An interesting history of the chemistry and physics involved in discovering the elements, organized by means of the periodic table. Well-researched and entertaining. Perhaps a bit longer than it needed to be.Favorite fun fact -- Antimony used to be used to treat various diseases by means of a pill. Because of antimony's chemical composition, it didn't dissolve in the digestive tract. It was also very expensive. So people would re-use the pills, sometimes even handing them down from parent to child. Yeesh.

This book mixed personal stories with scientific facts for a fascinating read. Science was never my strongest class in school so I was hesitant to start this book but I’m so glad I read it. It was interesting to know that politics play a huge role in scientific achievements. For example, certain sciences were pursued during war times and not for the better of mankind. certain female scientists weren’t given recognition because of their gender. Imagine what we could accomplish without those barriers!

No offense to left brain thinking scientists out there, but this book read like it was written by a scientist. The narrative -- I use that term loosely -- barely tied a series of interesting tidbits together. It read like someone standing and reading aloud one Trivia Pursuit card after another. which is a shame, because the tidbits WERE interesting. They just weren't enough to make it a good read.

Zoomed through this book. I shall have to skim through it again before giving it back. It has really extended the physics I have been reading about into chemistry. A great bridge between quantum physics and multiverses and the real world. (If it is real!) It's a jokey book with lots of human and historical interest as well as the chemistry/physics of the periodic table and I loved the mix and learned a lot.

It was really really good and captivating until the last 40 pages when Kean really only focused on radioactivity and physics (which isn’t my cup of tea at all). But the rest of the book was a fantastic read, I loved learning about how each of the elements were discovered and all the drama behind each discovery. It was well written and easy to understand and follow even if you don’t have a background in chemistry.

If you want to make a spoon that will disappear in hot water, use the element gallium; looks like aluminum, melts at 84 Farenheit. Generally following the structure of the chemistry of the periodic table, the author tells stories about many an element. The effectiveness of sulfa drugs against bacteria turns out to due in large part to the unusual chemistry of sulfur.

As heard on the NPR Books podcast.By the way: the "chemistry is boring" cultural trope needs to die right now, and I really don't appreciate your perpetuating it, NPR.I was sad this book was as short as it was. I know there are more stories about the elements to tell.

This book gives the history of the periodic table and discovery of the elements that are contained within. Author Sam Kean has arranged elements both into their well known groupings, but also into the groups of elements that share a commonalities. Well written, the anecdotal stories of the elements discovery and use help engage the reader in what could be a very boring story.

Chemistry for non-chemists. It started and ended slowly, but around the time he started talking about planets I got really into it. Around the time he got into chemistry in extreme temperatures, I was done.That said, he makes chemistry fun, especially the history and personalities that are involved.

I enjoyed this book. However, as usual, I am still not grasping some of the concepts presented here. I'll keep plowing on, hoping to really understand chemistry, etc. I will have to keep Kean on my mental list of authors to look for in new books. He writes well. My main problem may be more me, than the book: it just took me too long to read when I have so many other books screaming read me!

Billed as a book of stories, the author rambles rather than narrates. Although many are interesting, a 2 paragraph story on how so and so discovered this and got a noble prize does not make up for serveral pages explaining why electrons won't bond to form this or that. A book for only a true science geek.Damn you audible recommendations, I didn't enjoy this at all.

Stop anthropomorphizing electrons, you asshole.I just couldn't handle the scattered approach to the first few chapters. Keen just jumps from topic to topic too quickly and uses so many cute descriptive metaphors for my scientist brain. The drama of science is sometimes beautiful and hilarious, this just felt like a scattered gossip magazine.

I found this book interesting. I also found it boring. It also reminded me why I didn't like chemistry. It also reminded me that I'm not very smart. Would I recommend it to you? Only if you want to read something sort of interesting, boring, has lots of chemistry talk, and makes you feel sort of dumb...

This tuned out to be a hard book to read, but I'm only ten so I will probably come back to it when I'm a bit older. Although their was a bit of flipping around, the footnotes were interesting and now I know I'm going to love next school year, because we're going to learn about the Periodic Table of the Elements!

Not going to lie, parts of this were a real struggle for me. I am much more of a biology nerd; chemistry and physics have always been difficult for me to wrap my head around. However, there are so many fascinating antecdotal stories here. It was great to learn how the periodic table and elements themselves effected the history of science.

Kean does a good job of making the topic interesting by focusing on the stories behind the elements - how they were discovered and the intense rivalries between labs across the world. Even though I was enjoying this book, I just couldn't finish it. I overestimated my overall interest in chemistry and science.

Like his other books, Sam Kean does a great job of twisting history that spans the globe into a cohesive and interesting tale that takes you through the elements. Despite this, I find his writing was still not enough to further entice my (admittedly limited) interest in the subject, leaving me to like but not love this book.

Excellent book. The author elegantly moves from one story from the history of scientific discovery to the next using the elements of the periodic table as pivot points. Before I was halfway done this book, I was already eager to read it a second time.Edit: I've now read this book three times this year.

I challenged my son to learn the periodic table this summer. And I'm making an attempt to learn it too. This book definitely helped. I liked the stories about the scientists, although it does start to run together in the last third of the book. All in all, it was a good refresher for a non-chemist though.

Absolutely loved this book. The periodic table is a loosey-goosey way to organize these tales (as Kean demonstrates, you can tie anything back to the table), but, my-oh-my, what tales he has woven together! If you have a smidgeon of interest in science--and the history (and drama)--therein, this book is a must-read.

A diverse and interesting, if poorly organized at times, collection of origin stories for the elements. Accessible for all, but some some science background may be required to fully appreciate every detail. Lots of interesting endnotes with extra info, but I really wish they were footnotes; I did a lot of flipping.

It's a beautifully written book about how chemistry has changed the world, caused wars, created civilizations and a good overview of the search for elements in the world. The author tells us about the struggle and history behind inventions of elements and the work it took to get to the current level of understanding of chemistry. Must read for every chemistry lover!

History folks won't care for the science. Science folks won't care for the history. A good blend of each, although the atomic details were a bit over my head. Some really fascinating historical tidbits interspersed throughout.

I have to admit some of this book was above my chemistry know-how but I enjoyed much of the historical background. I thought that some of Kean's writing was pretty humorous. People have done some pretty crazy, uninformed things through out history.

This was a great book about the elements. Near the end though, it got a little boring. I've heard about those chemists for the last 20 years, so it was fun to read stories about their personalities and lives. Great book.

I just couldn't get into this book. Lots of information, and the author tried really hard to make it interesting. Unfortunately, it was too much like college chemistry, which wasn't all too pleasant the first time around.I finally decided I just wasn't enjoying it, and moved on.

An interesting collection of anecdotes about the various elements, although the periodic table framing device seems to be a little forced at times. Mostly a fascinating character study of the chemists, physicists, and other scientists who have shaped the way we look at matter today.

Tremendous fun and supremely informative, Kean's "Disappearing Spoon" is a great work of science-entertainment and a great resource for High School Chemistry teachers looking to pepper their lectures with interesting anecdotes.

Couldn't get through it. I though this book dragged on and did not keep my interest in the least. Unlike what I was promised in the introduction I did not find this book to be and enjoyable read. It was too slow paced.

Well written book that even I could understand. It is interesting how tied up every thing on the table seems to be. Mr Kean is a great writer and he is what Science needs. A good communicator that can write an important detailed book that even a meat head such as myself can understand.

It may be important for students to read this book, but it should be mandatory for all teachers of high school and college chemistry to read this book. If you want to know how to make the Periodic table appear as interesting as reading Tolkein, this book should be on your book shelf.

The concept itself is so beautiful - to make chemistry less rigid, less cold through the melding of science with art. The Disappearing Spoon injects these square and boring things with such rich history that it makes you want to hate Chemistry a little bit less.

This was a very fun read! Kean presents so much information on the discovery and creation of the period table we all know and does so without becoming dry or boring. The way he writes reads more like you're having a wonderfully nerdy history-of-science discussion over coffee.
